When I watched most of the series, I thought this anime was lacking seriousness.  However, I was proven wrong.  This anime does have action, love (shown in odd, eerie ways), and a couple unexpected plot twists.  The only downer with this show (at least in my opinion) are tiny placements of fan service (yuka's panty shots, swimsuit scene ODDLY PLACED MAKING ZERO SENSE, yuka's hideous obsession with the protagonist, Kakeru).  The story itself doesn't have much of a connection with one of the main characters (I refuse to give any spoilers to those interested) and having watched 10 episodes of thisseries I'm still curious as to how this show will unravel in just the final 2 episodes.  After the series progresses there's a definite love triangle and the two female characters involved will definitely have to settle it out themselves from some previous scenes I noticed.  Overall, I find this series so far just average because the story isn't too compelling and the silly connection between modern-day Japan and some Eastern European/Russian ripoff nation called Dracsavania or something like that.  If you like witches, young children fighting Black Knights (which are supposedly the good guys in this story), and silly inserts of Dark-Aged wannabe history, then this anime franchise is up your alley (thankfully this show will be short-lived as it will only span 12 episodes long and will stop airing shortly)!

I can sum this up in merely a few words:
Wasted potential.
The visual novel of 11eyes had everything all nicely set up to become a possibly well presented anime from what a few of my Japanese acquaintances have stated with the correct music chosen for scenes to portray the necessary feeling, characters were likeable and the story was superbly written with proper closure each time.
The story commenced with all the premise of being an enjoyable, supernatural themed anime with a bunch of kids introduced (the main cast) who would evidently hold some form of 'power' that would become dominant through the show as their own meansof fighting or supporting.\n
Fear not; this did not stop them from throwing all that potential out the door and following a very silly decision to become worse than most generic anime.\n\n
The musical selection was not bad but the voice actors themselves actually made me loathe most of the characters for how they were portrayed.\n\n
Overall, I give the anime a rating of:\n
2/10\n\n
The only reason it isn't a lower value is purely due to the fact it got so bad it was hilarious.

There is one question that people are constantly debating: Which is worse: movies based on video games, or video games based of movies? Judging by this show alone, I say that anime based off video games suck too. Yes, this was based of an Adult Visual Novel. But enough about that, lets dive right in to this failure and see why it... well.... failed.
The first problem itself is the actual plot. The red night, which I guess is a parallel dimension that comes and goes whenever the hell it feels like it (yeah it doesn't explain very well what it is. Get used to this.),traps a group of six teens inside of it and forces them to fight these black knights, and coincidentally, there happen to be six of them as well.  This plot was interesting at first, but it is killed by it's own uncreative nature later on. Everything was so predictable; their plot twists were so bland it makes you wander if they were really trying.  Like here's one of the genius plot devices they attempted to throw me on a loop with. We see our main protagonist Kakeru's sister die in the first episode, or at least that what they say what happened. I didn't know what was going on though, and if you see the way she supposedly "died", you'll be confused as hell too. Later on, a character that looks exactly like his sister joins the group, and Kakeru just sort of accepts it, and there's so many things wrong with that right there, but if I go over all the reasons you'll be reading this for about a day. Later on it turns out that she is his sister from yet another parallel dimension. Yeah, haven't seen that before. The lack of imagination here is truly a marvel of nature. 


As for the characters, well lets just say that it's very predicable too. I've seen these types of characters so many times in anime. Well actually, there is a difference. These characters are so much more lamer to the point that they're the bare minimum of "characters." Main male protagonist with a tragic past trying to protect his childhood friend, Yuka, check. Childhood friend who is obviously in love with the protagonist and gets jealous if any other girl tries to approach him, check. But the biggest failure of all is probably Misuzu Kusakabe, who starts out as a strong, Independent woman who actually saves Kakeru and Yuka all the time during the first few episodes of the show. She starts out as an interesting character, but then later on, after losing a fight to one of the black knights (who turns out to be one of her ancestors. I know, just go with it), she gets insanely depressed and practically gives up fighting,all just to make the Kakeru pick up the torch and start looking awesome. And as for the other characters, well, they're either forgettable or annoying. 


The only good thing about this series is the soundtrack, which is pretty awesome. Sadly though, most of them sound very insanely similar to each other, again, great creativity on their part. 


The art is okay, nothing special really. 


In conclusion, this anime is just a money making product. In fact, the production of this anime probably went something like this:


"Hey, why don't we make an anime based off a game, thus making quick money? We don't have to try to make it good or put actual effort into it, cause people who liked the game will buy this crap reguardless."


Do yourself a favor, and just don't watch it.

Interesting and dark conception in eroge adaptation. It was suppose to be bloody and mysterious but was shabby and schematic. Anime with wasted potential. 
Satsuki Kakeru lost his sister five years ego. She was his only family. Up till then the stepparents of Yuki Minase, his childhood friend took care of him. And then one day, when Kakeru and Yuki were returning from school, the moon turned red. They arrived to unknown alternative world, full of monsters and no humans. Presently they returned to their own world but they were aware this trip can repeat. When they arrive to the world with red moon again,they meet beings called Black Knights, that want to kill everyone who can travel to other worlds. Yuki and Kakeru along with three other school friends tries to protect themselves from attacks of mysterious beings.


And again we have an adaptation of eroge. The game “11Eyes” is a visual novel with some gore and sex scenes. The anime isn’t that typical eroge adaptation. We don’t have panties on half of screen. Sometimes pantyshots are shown in unsuitable moments, even in serious moments but it isn’t obtrusive that much. Concerning underwear scenes, there are fanservice situations but they are also important to the whole plot. They develop characters in some way. 


First episodes are really schematic. Teenagers spend their free time in school, try to find some information about the other world. Then the red moon appears and they must fight some monsters and defeat Black Knights. This formula repeat over and over and may be boring for a lot of people. 


All the time we have many uncertainties. This can attract some people. End includes some unexpected twists. Threads that were accepted at first sight are not that obvious. The puzzle which includes questions “Who is the girl in the crystal and why teenagers must safe her?” and “Why do Dark Knights wants to kill the children?”  Only this threads are interesting. The rest is quite boring. 


The story itself isn’t well adapt. The conception is quite interesting: girl from mage family, who uses five legendary katanas; assassin with attractive skills. All this characters with supernatural powers, little girl trapped in the crystal, Dark Knights with quaint design. This could go well. But the authors went wrong somewhere. There are many logic errors and shabby dialogs. The interesting conception was wasted. Instead of that we have teenager who stray over the place with no reason.


Everyone have some kind of supernatural skills, that helps them to fight the Dark Knights. Characters appears to be interesting at some point but the story doesn’t gave them opportunity to develop. Everything goes so fast, that the advantages can’t be notice. As if the authors want to accommodate everything that was in the game. Characters suddenly appears from nowhere, relocate to another place and we don’t even know when it occur. 


The character design are similar to that in the game. Pretty manga like faces doesn’t disturb the dark and brutal scenes. The backgrounds are very simple, but the profiles looks detailed. Apparently the anime is more censored compared to game, with erotic scenes as well as bloody moments. 


The music is well selected. When the red moon appears the chorus start to sing and when it’s time for a fight we have faster piece. There are moments with horror like themes but their goal is not to scare but to emphasize the atmosphere . Opening and ending songs are also climatic.


Regardless “11Eyes” is another wasted potential. It was suppose to be dark and bloody, with little bit mature erotic scenes. Somewhere the authors lost all ideas and it didn’t go well. Well done action anime, too lofty treated, that lead to shabby show. Sometimes it were original and interesting, sometimes boring and trivial.

11 Eyes could have been really excellent. It had plenty of things going right for it in the first episode that I was completely pulled in. I ended up watching this whole anime straight, and as I progressed, the quality of what I was watching slowly dwindled. The first episode arose so many questions, and as the anime attempted to answer them, the plot really started to make less and less sense. 
Art: 10
I really love the art of this anime, as this is what originally made me want to watch it. I found the main female protagonist (Yuka) very cute, especially in episode one.The villains are quite interesting, and everything looks really good.


Sound: 7

The sound wasn't as appealing to me. The voice actors did a good job, as expected of Japan. Sound effects are fair as well. I didn't find any background music very memorable or powerful, and I wouldn't remember any of it if I heard some now. I also didn't care for the opening or ending theme songs.


Plot: 2

This is the real problem with this anime. Its plot is good, it could easily be an excellent plot within the video game it came from. However, when told in the anime, it suffers from two issues: pace and script. this anime, like many others, is a twelve episoder. Most anime thats only twelve eps long suffer from the same issue of pacing. Twelve episodes honestly just isn't enough to tell a good story in. This anime, however, seemed to have been made with the idea that it was going to get more episodes, and then six episodes in the creators learned they only have six episodes left to finish the story. The first six or so episodes were good; they introduced new characters, developed current characters, blah blah. The last six episodes felt really rushed. This is a big problem too, as virtually all of the back plot is revealed in these episodes. Due to this, answers to certain questions made no sense sometimes, all contributing to a horrible ending. The script is the other issue. Besides just annoying script which dumbed down to'"Yuka, I will protect you!" and "Kakeru-kun" at least ten times per episode, the script is really stale. The characters feel really stereotypical and their words make it worse. Some major event could be going on in the story, and the character's script makes them sound like they have brain damage.


Characters: 3

This is the other problem with the anime. The characters in this anime all feel stereotypical, one dimensional, and brain-damaged. However, this isn't the main problem. The bigger issue comes from how they develop over the episodes. The main girl protagonist Yuka, like I said above, is extremely cute in episode one. However, as the episodes pass, she begins to become extremely hysterical and extremely possessive over the main boy protagonist. Its a degradation that is completely uncalled for and basically ruins an originally great character. The main boy protagonist Kakeru, has a brick instead of a brain, and is as uninteresting as it gets. Misusu, a red haired swordsman, like Yuka, starts off extremely interesting, but slowly degrades into mu. Misusu basically starts off the strongest character of the team, and slowly gets weaker and weaker for no reason at all until by the closing episodes she is the weakest of the team.Other characters suffer the same fate, though I will say that I felt the pyrokineticist was interesting till the end.  


Overall, this anime was bad. It did entertain me though, and I kept watching as I wanted to see what happened next. I theorize that had this anime been a healthy twenty six episode anime, it might have had more success pacing those later episodes, and developing the story better. However, those extra episodes wouldn't do any good unless a massive percent of the script had improvements. This anime was ok, but I wouldn't recommend it unless you don't mind being disappointed.

So disappointed in this anime that I can't be bothered with long paragraphs, so I'll just make warning as quick as possible.....

Okay. Great concept and starts off well but don't think the makers had a clue where to take the story and got too far ahead of themselves. *Just a warning this WILL contain spoilers, but hey you couldn't spoil this anime anymore if you tried*
In the beginning of this anime I felt that it had potential and had a place to go so I was intrigued and kept watching. Little did I know that this anime, 11eyes, would leave me utterly disappointed.
The action scenes and the overall battles were probably the only thing I decently enjoyed in this entire show. But even during these parts all I could think about was how bad the storyline was getting. In all honesty I'm all for supernatural shows with drama or love triangles within thembut this was saddening.


One thing that set me off during the show was that it turns out all the bad guys were actually good guys. Now I wouldn't have mind so much if they just executed it better rather than just saying "Your existence is a sin" to the main characters. Hell they tried to kill the main characters 1-1 though they could of teamed up against them to kill them or even ask them to join them in protecting the world (Or whatever they ended up protecting).


The next thing that set me off was the main character's power. Now I know having a power to see the future can be common in some magic shows and in all honesty it isn't always that bad, but they made his power go from just seeing attacks to just seeing the entire future!!! I mean c'mon they wasted a whole episode just on his vision and that alone ticked me off. What added to that was he got with my favorite character rather than the crazy girl he loves, which I'll get to in a min. In the end after seeing the vision he ended up moving slightly and changing it. However in the end the world still ended.


Yuka...is crazy. She tried to kill another "good guy", or were they bad guys...Any who she did that. And the main character still loves her which I can respect since I love Mirai Nikki, but she didn't do anything good the entire story either for their cause or for her love.


My last point is the ending. Oh this gosh darn ending. After killing off many of the characters and saying O well there is nothing more anyone can do they destroy the world. Great huh. But then the three that are left go to a different universe and everything is okay...What. The. Hell. So in the end the entire story is meaningless and all the deaths are meaningless because they went somewhere else...


That's all I basically have to say. Though I could talk about the different universes and the sister or angel that the writers threw in there but I would rather not. In the end this is just a rather disappointing show overall. All I could do is try to forget it ever happened, or hope it was all from a vision and it turns out I never actually watched it.

11eyes is what i'd call for now a "victim anime" those kind of shows that try too hard to please everyone with combinations of action, fanservice and a strong plot, but ultimately end up being lackluster in everything...
-> The story is about a parallel dimension ("Red Moon Night") and some highschool students who entered on this zone for some strange reason. They all have special powers, and in the Red Moon Night dimension they fight against the Black knights, this is the basic premise of the show.
-> Later, while remaining kinda episodic with the Red Moon events, the plot gets some twists and gets deeper,involving more and more stuff and relating it with the premise with the purpose of having a strong, complex show. 


-Overall, the plot isn't really bad and the twists, although predictable, conserve some logic, but there are plotholes, and big ones.. In fact, when analyzing the plot you get absolutely no reason of why the students were forced to enter the "Red Moon Night" on the first place, therefore nullifying the premise, and of course, eventually all the story, it just doesn't make sense once you get all the pieces.


-> The art and sound of 11eyes was pretty decent in my opinion and a strong quality of this show, both the art and sound helped to get  into the "Dark" environment that the Red Moon Night was supposed to be, with some graphic violence here and there to make the things more impressive. It works, and it works well, so no complaints here


-> 11eyes also tries to have action and romance, but in both aspects failed miserably, on "action" there isn't much scenes worth of mentioning, and worse yet, what could have been the best scenes, are either cut to continue the story in another place, or never happen. To avoid the spoilers i will just say "The ultimate battle is something you don't watch"


->The romance is basically a jealous driven love triangle between Yuka, Kakeru and Misuzu, the 3 main characters, but the problem here is Yuka becomes an extremely awkward character, ruining everything (and serving as a lame trigger to the situation of the final episodes). As for Misuzu, she spends more time dealing with her own feelings instead of competing for Kakuro, and worse, Kakuro was never doubtful.. So in the end you have an awkward character resulting from an imaginary, and ergo, no romance


-> The last major problem of 11eyes resides on character development, because as soon as Kakeru "awakens" his power the rest of the cast slowly becomes less and less relevant.. The show also gets "deus ex machina" at times, maybe because the show wasn't clearly enough with the concept of "dimensions"...


In conclusion, 11eyes left a bittersweet taste because it had the potential to become something awesome but it just doesn't, still as i said earlier, the plot doesn't fall into complete nonsense and you can actually get some enjoyment from it, i did, at least for the first half of the anime.


Story 6/10

Art 8/10

Sound 9/10

Character 4/10

Enjoyment 5/10

Overall 6/10

Where can I start? Well, it's been fun to analyze this show for my first review. So, let's get to it, even though i'm late by about 8 years, hopefully you guys go easy on me:
Art/Animation- 
There is not much to talk about here. Since this anime is from 2009 and I didn't see too much older anime, it surprised me that the art was pretty good. However I personally don't like the style of the female characters, where their face almost always looks the same, though I believe that is personal preference.
Sound- 
This was actually pretty interesting. The OST itself is really good. However,I noticed (mostly at the beggining) that while the sound fits the location it did not always fit the situation and the characters. I think this would have been amazing on a video game for example, where sometimes the music only plays for the location you are at. Not many would notice that though, so I would still say that it is good. The voice acting is pretty normal as well, apart from some cringy parts; can't blame the voice actors though, it's not the sound.  \n
As for the OP and ED, I always believe that whether or not you like the song and music is decided by your own preference. The animation is a pretty normal showcase of the characters for both OP and ED, though I did notice that there are some things some may consider spoilers in them, and it tries to get a bit too dramatic in the opening, to a level I would call cringy. It's not bad though, and I did like the songs. \n\n
Story-\n
And now we start going down. I must say, the story itself is not so bad as I expected it to be from reviews I read. While not the most original, it's base is very solid as you may notice in the first few episodes, and does what's is supposed to do quite well, and executing the genres it shows in a pretty good way. Though, as a drama lover, I noticed some forced drama (though not too much) and pretty bad one as well, some of it felt like it was ment for kids. Though this is not the worst, it did hurt the experience a bit. Thankfully fanservice did not interfere too much, something I was worried about. So what keeps this show from getting a higher score you may ask? That title goes to a part some may consider to be a part of the story, but I would say it needs it's own part here.\n\n
Characters- \n
If you read what I said about the story itself, you will probably know- The characters are probably the worst part of this show. Oh, where to start; Probably my least favorite deuteragonist of all time, which means alot, since I usually hate them. Usually the quality of a character is shown by it's role in the story, and how well it does what it's supposed to do. In this case, not only is she a bad character, but only one who has a personality that makes you want to hate her. That would be fine if that was her role, but she is the one the main character fights to protect so much and every one of the characters love her. If you don't hate her at the beggining you will later. And hey, you know that character who is supposed to be the most annoying at first, as if he is ignorant of everything? He is actually the least annoying of all. On the first half I came prepared to tell you how bad the antagonists are, though that did change for good (A BIT) on the second half. Most characters execute their role poorly, some don't even have a clear one. There are many more things I want to say about this, but they contain spoilers, so if you are really curious you will need to watch the show for yourself. \n\n
OVA- \n
I don't want to write a full review for the OVA which is usually considered episode 13. I would just say it is pretty funny after watching the show, though contains 100% more fanservice and is much more perverted then the main show, some may not like that. Still, if you did finish the show I would reccomend you check it out. \n\n
Final Thoughts/Personal Opinion- \n
I do not believe this show is deservant of more then 8/10 , but also not of less then 5/10. It was average in my opinion. I must say, it was pretty fun to watch, but the problems were made apparent. I think you should watch it if you don't have much to do, or if you want to analyze and think what are the negatives and positives are for yourself like I did, which I found really fun, though I don't want that to change the ratings I give for the show. Personally I think it deserved a 6/10, "Fair", but I would understand anyone who would give it 5 or 7.

She's badass and seems to know what she's doing – but, as the story progresses, she gets completely sidelined and becomes dependent on Kakeru. Kakeru is meh, basically every generic, personality-less male lead ever. 


Yuka is definitely the most irritating character I've seen in anime. She's actually dumb, endlessly walking into traps and at one point, straight-up tried to murder Misuzu?? I suppose cos the show was hopping on the yandere bandwagon. I'm surprised Misuzu didn't say shit about it and it was never brought up again


The rest of the supporting cast feel like they're there to fill up the space. I really enjoyed this anime, though it did have some major flaws. 
Animation: 7/10
The characters were drawn very well, and the scenery was okay as well. However, some of the action scenes were animated very poorly. One of the characters, who is supposedly very strong, seems slow and not very skilled in many of these scenes. The sword fighting is just people waving their swords a little and using the same blocks over and over again. Other than that, however, the animation was good.
Voice Acting: 10/10
I didn't think there was anything wrong with this. Their voices were not monotonous, and you could tell what theywere felling.\n\n
Characters: 7/10\n
This was okay, but the characters were extremely cliche, and it seemed that sometimes the characters weren't needed, and then killed off later. Also, there was character development in some characters, but none at all in others.\n\n
Story: 6.5/10\n
The story started out fine. However, there are many plot holes within this anime, and things weren't explained clearly, creating some confusion. It also seemed rushed. It goes at a steady pace until the last half of the last episode, where it seems like they didn't have any time, so they just killed off the bad guy with one shot. The entire resolution and epilogue is rushed into the last few minutes.\n\n
Enjoyment: 8/10\n
I really enjoyed this anime. It kept me excited for each episode, and I didn't get bored at all. The only reason I give this an 8 is because of the holes in the plot, and the mistakes in the animation of the sword fighting. ﻿

The art (Marvelous Entertainment...  ) is amazing almost on par with Kyoto Animation.  The sound is great... the music is cool, with the right mix of serious undertones.. and fun ones..
Some of characters are something else too, I will focus on three of them. Kakeru (played by the brilliant Daisuke Ono) is not your normal orphan.  He has the "Eye of Aeon" which helps him see moves before the enemy makes the move (theUS Government wishes they had a weapon like that)... Yuka is a girl who is his friend and was a orphan too until she was adopted... Misuzu is a awesome sword-fighting miko with healing powers...\n\n
I have really enjoyed the battle scenes in this, they are stunning but can be bloody so this anime is not for the faint of heart.  Overall, I have really liked this amine, and I hope it ends on a high note.

example: someone goes and tells another that a certain someone has died in battle yet it never actually showed the battle in which they died, which was a big disappointment.

11eyes had a lot of potential to be an exciting and a really good anime, but the characters were stiff, which they tend to be when the anime is a visual novel adaption. You can see how the studio tries to get their characters deeper, but they don't succeed.
It also explains why the plot occasinally became weak, but it never became unwatchable. Most visual novel adaptions (that I've seen) have had a happy and bright feel to it, but 11eyes is different because the theme is more darker.If you like dark animes and fighting scenes with gore, I think you will enjoy this one.\n\n
The anime might have been better if they had skipped the forced ecchi parts. Overall it wasn't a bad anime. It was quite thrilling sometimes. I liked it.\n

11eyes’ story centers around our main characters, 
Kakeru Satsuki, and Yuka Minase, who are both just normal high school students. However, their realities fall apart when they are suddenly dragged into this strange world known as the “Red Night.”  Except for some red fog that covers the area this world looks almost identical to the world Kakeru and Yuka know. Our heroes are in for even more of a surprise when these grotesque monsters start to attack them. Right when it looks like it’s all over, Kakeru and Yuka are suddenly transported back to their own world with their mental scars being the onlyproof that they had ever been there. Kakeru and Yuka, along with a few others, are dragged back in and out of the Red Night constantly without warning as these creatures called the “Black Knights” mercilessly hunt our heroes down. Only those brought to the Red Night are aware of its existence, while everyone else is blissfully ignorant. Now some other stuff happens of course, but that’s how the story unfolds for the most part. Now if you’re like me this story may seem kind of familiar to you. It may remind you of  Persona 3 perhaps. The Red Night reminds me pretty heavily of the Midnight Hour. Not only that, but the monsters look like something straight out of P3. The whole anime also feels like it’s going for that darker more serious tone of storytelling like P3 as well. I mean, even Kakeru looks like a somehow edgier version of the P3 protagonist that they decided to slap an eye patch on. None of this means I think it was inspired by P3 by any means, but as a giant Persona fan the similarities are definitely interesting and worth noting.

I think the premise of the story is actually pretty interesting. I really enjoy the idea that these characters can suddenly be dragged into this other world at any time without warning. It’s just kind of a shame how the story unfolds for most of the anime. Our heroes are dragged into the Red Night, they are then hunted down by the Black Knights, our heroes often kill one of them, and then rinse and repeat. The second half of the anime is way more interesting, though. I will say that the pacing of the story can feel a little off at times. Episode 12 of the series is pretty rushed, and the episode before that had a neat concept, but I think they used it mainly for shock value and as such, was mostly unnecessary. There was an episode 13, but we won’t talk about that. Episode 12 is the real ending. 13 was pretty funny to watch but was one of the oddest most unnecessary episodes of an anime I’ve ever watched. Now I won’t go into the ending for obvious reasons, but I will say I actually liked it more than most people seem to. Well, more accurately, I like the spiral of event that leads to the end. Episode 12 leaves a lot to be desired honestly.




Oh, boy, grab some popcorn everyone, It’s time to talk about the characters. I prefer to call Kakeru “Edgy McEdgelord,” after his personality, or I’m sorry, his lack of one. Kakeru is your typically “Look at me, I have a tragic past that made me cold” type of main character. He never shuts up about how he’ll protect Yuka at any cost, which in all fairness, Yuka is such a useless character that she needs protecting. Yuka exists purely to grow Kakeru’s own ego and help him fulfill his brave, strong, alpha male, main character role. Everything from Kakeru’s character design, the way he talks, and his actions all bleed edginess. I could seriously slice bread on this man’s edge. His edginess could definitely be annoying to some, but I find pretty funny more than anything else, which makes it impossible for me to take him, as well as this anime serious. As I mentioned about Yuka, she’s useless. I wish I had more to comment about, but aside from the random out of place panty shots they use her for (which only makes it harder to take this anime seriously) she’s completely useless, uninteresting and exists purely to be protected by our Edgelord. Now, for the most part, everything I just said about Yuka is true, however for reasons I can’t go into without spoiling stuff Yuka gets infinitely more interesting towards the end of the anime, so keep that in mind. As for other characters, you have Yukiko Hirohara, a loud energetic girl that actually has a pretty interesting backstory, although the anime doesn’t go into depth about it as much as I’d like, which is a shame. I find her more annoying than anything else most of the time. She goes around randomly groping girls because they need to please the perverts, of course. You have Takahisa Tajima, he’s your typical delinquent. Aside from the fact that he’s eating food in almost every scene, which is a little humorous, he’s pretty boring. Next is Misuzu Kusakabe, my personal favorite character, not that that’s saying much. My reason for liking Misuzu is mainly because I think she’s the coolest character in the series and, who like Yukiko, has a pretty interesting backstory that isn’t fleshed out very much sadly. Next is Kukuri Tachibana, who seems to have lost her ability to speak, and communicates by writing on a notepad because of it. She seems to resemble Kakeru’s sister who took her own life many years ago. Can’t go into much without spoiling things, but I will add that I think Kukuri has a really cute smile. Not sure why that’s the main thing that sticks out to me, but she does. There are other characters, but that covers the main cast for the most part.




The art is the anime is pretty decent. It’s not going to win any awards or anything, but it looks fine for its time and I’ve never really noticed any drops in quality. The way the monsters are designed is again fine. The most common monsters in the Red Night may look like something straight out of an RPG, but they are actually pretty creepy. The way their jaws drop and let out this bloodcurdling whale like scream is actually slightly terrifying, so I give the anime major points for that. The sound and visual effects that happen when the Red Night begins is also pretty eerie and intense. The opening song for the series (Arrival of Tears) gives off that nostalgic vibe that I often get from older anime, and I really enjoy it. The song and visuals fit the themes in the show really well. Overall Arrival of Tears is catchy and fits the anime, which is all an opening really needs to do. Sequentia the ending song of 11eyes, like the opening, gets its job done. Once again the song itself is decently catchy and fits the show as it provides a nice wind down after the cliffhangers this anime loves to throw at the end of its episodes.




11eyes is an anime that really had the potential to be great, but unfortunately, it fell short in its generic underdeveloped characters as well as it’s execution.

That being said 11eyes isn’t all bad. Regardless of what I’ve said I actually enjoyed watching through it quite a bit and found it really exciting. I mean, I binged episodes 7-13 in one sitting. With all that being said, I always believe you should watch the anime yourself and build your own opinion. Everything I wrote here is just my own opinion after all and it isn’t any more or less valid than anybody else’s.

This had a great potential, which was absolutely crashed by poor budget. No, seriously. Either the budget was miserable, or this anime had an idiot for a director. I can't help, but feel bitter about this, but I guess, it can't be helped.
So, about the story. As I said before, it had a pretty amazing potential indeed, but unfortunately, the story develops from a very wrong point. Yes, the concepts like this are pretty common, but that would be forgivable, if the events were set right. However, in this case, the development is pretty fragmented and corrupt. A lot of important moments were missing, alot of important moments weren't set right. Story development takes 6/10 points.\n
As for the art, it was the thing that made me start watching this. Until today, the art of 11eyes remains one of my favorites. The characters were designed nicely, even though the concentration point was moe, there weren't much unnecessary details, like ridiculously big and bouncing boobs. There were pantyshots, but that's okay. Aside from the art itself, the animation wasn't so good and that disappointed me very much. art & animation get 8/10\n
Sound was the best part about this anime. Starting from the SFX, onto the OST, OP-ED themes, everything was pretty much amazing. Opening and ending sequences were really good, soundtracks were lively, strong and just made you listen to them. I also liked the twisted Gothic feel of the music. SFX were just top notch, so Sound part gets 10/10. \n
Character design was pretty poor, almost all of them were standard personality types, like the cute yandere Yukiko and a tsundere - Tajima. Sometimes, some of them were utterly annoying and only a couple of characters saving the show. Character composure takes 6/10 points.\n
The enjoyment part is the most interesting one, in fact. Even though the anime isn't that good, I, personally, enjoyed it very much. The storyline development was poor, the characters were annoying, animation was pretty rough, but I still liked it. Somehow, the atmosphere of the show itself makes it enjoyable and pleasant to watch. Enjoyment takes 8/10.\n
Overall, the show was not that special, but still outstanding from most of the others, with who knows what. I'll say it again - the atmosphere of the show was very captivating, thanks to the decent art and amazing music, with poor storyline and character composure opposing it. Overall, the show gets 6/10 points. \n
If you're looking for an anime that in pleasant to WATCH and LISTEN to, then 11eyes is just for you. However, if you need some thinking material and are looking for a solid, composed plot with it's twists and what not, then stay away from this.\n\n

Story 6/10
The story was okay, but a little vague. They don't really tell you what's going on until the end. In the beginning it was pretty good but everything suddenly got VERY strange and shifted around a lot. In the beginning it started out with some high school kids who got taken to this alternate version of the world, fighting these black knights, with really no explanation whatsoever. The Black Knights don't even explain why they're trying to kill them. Then everything just got a little odd...and because I'm trying to not include any spoilers, I can't say anymore. So for it being good inthe beginning, I'll give it a 6 for story.


Art 8/10


Now the art I think was pretty amazing. I love the way the hair and eyes were drawn, and I just think it was very good. The only problem I have is how they're only in their school uniforms the entire time. Nothing like kicking some Black Knight butt in my school uniform. So they pretty much didn't have any protection or anything. They could have gotten some battle outfits or something once they enter the Red Night. But for the animation and art being good most of the time I give it an 8.


Sound 8/10


Now I think the sound was pretty awesome. It's not really memorable, but it set up a good scene sometimes. I absolutely LOVE the opening song, "Arrival of Tears" and the ending song, "Sequentia". Opening by Ayane and ending by Asriel. The opening really pulled you into the show and the ending song closed it off very well. For the opening and ending songs being so awesome, I give it an 8.


Character 4/10


The characters were pretty boring but some of them were pretty interesting. Lets go through the list of characters...


Yukiko Hirohara - A minor character that disappears easily. I kind of like how when she takes off her glasses she's suddenly all dark and pulls out daggers. That was pretty cool since she's normally the bubbly hyper type. But if she's immortal, then wouldn't she know a little more about the Red Night if she's been around all this time?! That's the only thing that makes sense.


Kusakabe Misuzu - She's your typical "I accidentally fell in love with someone who can never be mine." person. She's also your typical shrine maiden who can use swords. Nothing really cool about her but I swear at the end when Kakeru and her do that thing to get stronger? Yeahh I kinda wonder if that was just an act so she can just have sex. Also she's the one that does most of the work I think.


Satsuki Kakeru - You're typical main character who's the "What? I'm just a clueless normal teenage boy! I don't have anything to do with this!" type. He barely knows how to fight, and the thing with seeing the future with the golden eye under his eye patch, I wonder if he's secretly Raven Simone from That's So Raven. He doesn't do a whole lot, he just wants to protect Yuka, whom I would've given up on because Yuka gets VERY annoying.


Tachibana Kukuri - Kakeru's sister who shows up for a while but writes down everything she says because she can't talk. She committed suicide when Kakeru was younger and then she comes back as a ghost and she just kinda chills there no real explanation and no one really seems to care either. She has a cool attack with the chains and stuff but she's pretty boring.


Minase Yuka - She was originally typical girl who was being protected by Kakeru but after Kakeru and Misuzu start becoming close friends Yuka becomes a total creeper and stalks Kakeru and comes outside in her underwear all "Don't you love me?" and becomes VERY creepy and stalkerish and not to mention a beyotch. And her attack? Stopping those around her from using their powers. So she's very annoying.


Tajima Takhisa - Your typical angry all the time, food loving, "I'm stronger than you type." Not much to say cause all he does is light his hands on fire and destroy stuff. Very boring and uninteresting.


Everyone is pretty stereotypical but some of their attacks are cool so I give it a four.


Enjoyment 6/10


There were boring parts, there were WTF moments, this is very awkward and weird, and I found some parts to be interesting. So I'll give a 6/10.


Overall 6/10


Overall, 6/10. It got some points because of the art and sound and the story and enjoyment being somewhat good. The characters were decent but it was a fair show. Probably never watching it again, since the anime isn't very memorable.

Very much wasted potential with this anime. Started out decently, with an interesting premise then devolved into something it never should have become.
So without further ado, let's begin...
Story - 4/10
What was an interesting, though not original, concept soon turned sour. At first it comes across as quite intriguing - what is the Red Night? Why are these kids transported into it? Why are they different? All this is answered, though I had to watch the last couple of episodes more than once to make sense of what in the world just happened. After the original introduction of the story, things take a turn for theworse, story-wise. It becomes more of a "look how useless these females are in comparison to the male lead" type affair and seems to discard actual logic in favour of butchering the other characters to make the lead appear better.


Wat?


Art - 6/10

Nothing special, just slightly above average. Caters to people who like the "moe" style females (big eyes and whatnot). The mirror world is just the normal world but red-coloured. Missing potential here I feel - could have been taken further as it was a decent concept. The black knights' design is pretty good, but poorly done. I found the fighting scenes awkward to watch for the most part, they seem pretty mediocre, as if not much effort was expended to make them awesome.


Sound - 7/10

I really enjoyed the OP and the ED of this series. The OP sets us up for what could be an epic, action-filled 20 minutes, however at some points I enjoyed the OP more than the actual episode. Use of sound outside the OP and ED was nothing special really, it was mostly unnoticed by myself but managed to set the scene. Probably the best thing about this anime.


Character - 4/10

Really obvious cut-and-paste archetypal characters. I think there is one of most of the -deres here, which annoys me to no end. Character development went out of the window when they decided everyone was useless except the male lead.


But I digress, let me give character a proper review. At first it had the potential to be interesting. Kakeru and Yuka react to the red night with realistic confusion and fright, and have to be protected by Misuzu, a feisty swordswoman. There was potential here for a great character development, as I hoped we would see Kakeru fight to become strong enough to protect Yuka, which was his aim in the first place, helped by Misuzu. But, sadly, my hopes were too high and instead he suddenly becomes the strongest of the group, whereas the other characters who started out sort of interesting become a pile of quivering jelly in comparison.

The devolution of the characters was the most frustrating part for me.


Enjoyment - 6/10

The first little bit of the series was interesting for me. It's a relatively new concept for me personally, although it isn't original, I enjoyed how the characters acted and interacted. Then the frustration began as the series seemed to let go of any logical sense. Enjoyment gets a 6 - it started well, but the latter half of the series was difficult to enjoy a whole lot.


Overall - 5/10

A lot of wasted potential in this anime due to bad writing and a very thin plot. The only real saving grace, for me, was the sound, and the first couple of episodes were decent.

Every once in a while we are able to find that diamond in the rough. That one anime that you never expect to impress you that ends up being amazing. The anime that makes you cherish the genre and make you reflect on your actions. That however, is not the case with this anime. No, it is the exact opposite. 
________________________________________
The Opening Theme is more exciting than the actual Anime
________________________________________
Story: The story is completely unoriginal and the plot... well there really isn't a plot. The main character is someone who has faced a tragedy and has gone into generic anime depression (the unrealistic type ofdepression that itou fell into in school days when no girl wanted to have sex with him any more) is suddenly forced to fight for survival with a poorly written yandere. The eventual climax of the story feels botched and miss represented, and the final 2 episodes will ultimate go down as one of the worst endings I've ever seen. One thing I've realized is that good anime don't leave their endings open ended. There may be some questions that still need to be answered, but the writers are practically begging to producers to give them more money to fund a sequel.  


For the love of god, no thank you.


As I mentioned, we have a generic main character with a "tragic" back story involving suicide. The problem is the suicide and the effects of the suicide are not even explored, we are just told that he is depressed and needs someone to help him. There have been anime that have been exceptional when it comes to exploring the theme of depression and suicide (A Silent Voice comes to mind as done Serial Experiments Lain), and there have been garbage anime that have done a decent job with it in the past when I have least expected it (Charlotte is the best example of a bad anime that somehow handled depression accurately), 11eyes just ignores that. Instead they turn this premise into a generic action anime with underwhelming fights, a weak climax, and a fake out ending


Characters: I don't want to spend to much time on the characters because I feel like I would be insulting the producers if I did so. Its clear that the goal was to make everyone one dimensional and completely unmemorable. The main character is more bland than Otonashi and the supporting characters are archetypes you would expect to see in an anime with this low of a score.


Animation & Sound: The animation is this shows saving grace. While it wasn't anything special, it was pleasant to look at and helped me breeze through the series so I could get it behind me. The Opening Theme is amazing and was something that I could listen to over and over again. 


Enjoyment & Impact: Honestly I should have given this anime up. But by the time I was ready to throw this anime away, I was on episode 7 and figured "why not?" For me it did require a little dedication to get through, which is incredibly bad for a moe anime. The impact is there, but not in the way that the producers had hoped. This anime annoyed me more than anything, and that is the worst kind of feeling an anime can give you.


________________________________________


With that all being said, here is how 11eyes stands in my scoring system.

Plot, Sequence, and Flow: 0.5/3

Characters and their development: 0.2/2

Impact and Enjoyment: 0.4/2

Visual Effects and Audio Effect: 1/2

Memorability: 0/1

Overall Score: 2.1/10


I have finished around 200 anime, and 11eyes currently holds a spot in my bottom 10.

There's a certain type of anime I hate to rate on here, the ones that start off god but have a terrible ending or last few episodes. What do you do? Do you rate them based off of the terrible ending, or do you ignore the ending and give it the rating you were going to give it before the show got bad? 11 Eyes is definitely one of those shows. 
11 Eyes is based off of a visual novel and it is directed by Shimoda Masami, who also did Saber Marionette J and the original Someday's Dreamers. It tells the tale of Kakeru, yourtypical high school student with a slightly dark past who lives a normal life with his clingy childhood friend Yuka. One day him and Yuka get transported to another world called the Red Night, where monsters begin to attack them. A little while later, they get transported back to Earth, however, they soon get transported back to the Red Night, and then go back to Earth again. They can be transported there at any time. . In the Red Night, they meet other teenagers who are also transported there, and they try to figure out what's going on while staying alive. 


11 Eyes certainty has a good premise. The fact that you never know when they could go into the Red Night adds a layer of tension to the show, as you never know when they could go there. They even got transported there during a comedic scene once. However, especially in the beginning episodes, they spend more time in the real world than the Red Night. Actually, this show starts out really really slowed paced. It takes until episode 5 for the last main character to be finally introduced. However, this slow-paced was welcomed, as 11 Eyes is not an action show first, but a mystery show, as these kids try to find out what's going on. And it can do that good. The show takes its time fleshing out its characters and setting, taking tiem to show that these are ordinary high school students and not just tools for the plot. The comedic scenes also work too and don't feel out of place at all either. Sure they aren't that funny, but they aren't painful to watch either, and they're dropped around the halfway point. When the show gets bad.


Well, okay, maybe it's more of the two-thirds point where the quality really begins to drop, but still. The thing is, 11 Eyes is a 12 episode show, okay? But the thing is, the first 6 episodes were paced with the speed of a 24 episode show. While I love slow-paced stuff, around episode 8, the writers realized this. Chances are that the way they ended it needed 8 episodes to end properly, but they only had 4, so everything gets compressed and it is a mess. Multiple parts happens in one episode which each character doing something, which I typically love, but they don't know how to direct 4 plots going at once, making it tough to tell what's going on. Also, due to the fact they don't explain anything for a while, episode 10 is more or less one of the characters explaining all of the plot. Which is done badly and opens up so many holes in this show. Episode 11 doesn't really even have a point and can almost be considered filler when looking back. And episode 12, Oh my god. 4 minutes from the end I thought I was wrong about this show having 12 episodes and thought it had to be 13 the climax was that bad. Actually, this ending is my fifth least favorite anime ending, and I've seen a whole lot of shows with endings I hate. These final episodes were just so sloppily put together it's almost an insult.


Fortunately, the characters remain good throughout. Kakeru is your normal protagonist who just wants to protect his childhood friend Yuka. Yuka is well, the childhood friend of the clingy type, so clingy she turns yandere later on in the show which actually makes a little sense. There's also Kusabake Misuzu, your sword-wielding badass girl.  While they are 3 other main characters, they all appear rather late in the show that going over them would almost be spoilers. While most of the characters are built on your typical harem stereotypes, they are fleshed out well enough and grow out of their roles into multi-layered characters. They all develop nicely enough.


The animation. Well, it looks good for sure. The character designs are very cute and moe looking and look very pretty. However, it doesn't really move that fluidly. Characters typically stand in one place when they talk, the waving hair animation is looped and they just animate the mouth, typical techniques like that this anime is filled with. It's not distracting though as the character designs are really good, but still.


This show does have an awesome soundtrack backing it. The opening theme is rather catchy if a little generic sounding, and the ending theme is awesome with an unique sound to it. The backing tracks are also of a high quality and add to whatever atmosphere the show wants. The voice acting is very average too and I think Misuzu's looks don't exactly fit her voice, but it's still decent enough.


Story- Great start, terrible last four episodes with a few noticeable plot holes- 6. 

Characters- Well-fleshed out for a 13 episode show and manage to stray away from their archetypes-8.

Art- Great character designs without much fluid movement- 7. 

Sound- Good opening and ending themes, good backing track, average voice acting- 8.

11 Eyes is a tough show to recommend simply due to the fact it really falls apart in the end. I give it a 7, and say watch it if you can handle the fact this show really derails in the end, as the rest of it is rather good.

I enjoyed 11eyes, it really gave me a scenario where I am able to think about what would happen if I found out I was a special kid with powers.
This anime really helped me think about how great it is to live and just being who you are. 
The story and the art were both okay, there were some parts where I thought it wasn't really necessary to have but each one built itself to the climax and resolution.
Those who enjoy action packed, full of drama, sort-of romance, and powers from the supernatural, then you will enjoy 11eyes!

Story 7:  An anime with a story that involves mysteriously being transported to a another world and surrounded by monsters, while it does sounds like a well used initial premise, I found that in 11 Eyes it was necessary.  Comments on cliche's aside, I found the overall story to this anime to be good.  In a standard 12 episode anime, you would hope that the story is decent and not rushed and that's generally what 11 Eyes does.  This anime was my first real dive into a supernatural anime and the concept of the Red Night was one of my favoriteparts of this show.  The idea that you could be made to survive in a dangerous parallel universe at any moment in time was appealing and fun to watch.  The story's direction though was something I am split on.  On the one hand you had a brilliant set up that could've very easily made sense until completion but it was the sheer changes in direction towards the end that confused me.  I won't comment on what happened per se to avoid spoiling but let's just say the ending though it was explained, left me a little confused and perhaps wishing for just a bit more.



Art:

I'm not the biggest art critic in the world when it comes to Anime but I will say the art in this show was great.  The thing that sticks out most for me was that awesome glass breaking scene that came up every time they went in the Red Night.  The cityscape, background characters and the entirety of the Red Night were pretty and served to make the sense of darkness/twilight greater when it was necessary.  The characters were all well done as well, my favorites being Misuzu and Kakeru.  Misuzu because of her eyes and expressions, Kakeru for his Aeon eye.  


Sound:

Ok the sound in this anime is just fantastic.  Everything from the intro, to the ending music is just awesome.  I'm sure the other reviews list the names of the soundtracks but what I'd like to draw attention to is the amazing levels of contrast the sound selection offers to the feel and theme of this anime.  The juxtaposition of soundtracks with that almost aggressive feel using that electric guitar sounds so much better when it plays after the ending scenes in every episode.  It helped the show carry a tone of seriousness and kept me in anticipation for the next episode.


Character:

As one who has mainly watched longer animes up until now, I will say the character development in this show was good given that it had only 12 episodes.  Granted a lot of animes have this standard of 12 episodes the characters in this show were all very unique with a few exceptions (YUKA).  I won't go over all the characters but the following three are highlights for me:


Kakeru:  Ok so he is the MC, he is the protagonist, etc.  That aside initially I hated his character for how cliche the whole orphan/alone in the world thing is.  As the series wound on I started tolerating him and eventually like his character.  While i wholeheartedly understand his unconditional care/concern for Yuka being a result of how much she was there for him as a kid, I always hated that no matter what crazy thing Yuka did, Kakeru still insisted on being with her.  What's more infuriating about this guy was how many times he had to repeat that he'd protect her and all that bravery crap.  6/10 for Kakeru.


Yuka:  Alright so I hated this character.  If i had a delete button I'd use it on Yuka.  "Why would you delete one of the main characters DisarmingStar?"  Well ordinarily I wouldn't but Yuka went from clingy, weak and annoying to Clingy, strong, and crazy in a matter of two episodes!  Like i found her annoying at best prior to her becoming an obsessed maniac but my god that shift in character does absolutely nothing for me I still hate her!  "So then why is Yuka a highlight?"  That's because she does something very refreshing and that is stop being the damsel in distress and start being the crazy chick who gets her way!  In so many animes I've seen female characters start well and end up all weak, in others I've seen them just stay weak but not Yuka!  As much i hated her character the fact that she became a crazy chick and not some who gets weak around the MC was really nice to see 8/10.


Misuzu:  Ah yes my favorite character.  Here is a female character I like to see, well drawn, well conceived, a great backstory, wonderful voice acting, strong character (in design and in power) and she remains relevant throughout the entire anime.  Even though the show is called 11 Eyes I had no idea they'd do such a great job drawing the eyes for her and kakeru.  Her expressions combined with those deep eyes were very expressive and she just ends up being a really good character.  Granted eventually she too does fall for the MC, this is by far my favorite character in the show.


Enjoyment:  Maybe my rating for this is a bit high but this is my first supernatural themed anime and I liked it.  Granted im no expert on animes of this genre I say the plot was engaging and the characters' stories interesting enough to where I had a fun time watching it.  It had slight comic relief in the form of those two side characters which was very nice as some animes take comic relief way too far.  At the very least I was interested in seeing the next episode everytime i finished one.


Overall:  Look its an anime that's generally enjoyable and has awesome sound.  Some of the characters drive me nuts, others I think are awesome.  If you wanted a new anime to watch and didn't have a genre preference then I'd totally recommend this anime, its not that bad.

When I first decided to watch 11eyes, I tried to keep my expectations limited. However, the opening was incredible to watch and to listen to and the first episode definitely drew me in.  My high hopes for the anime soon faded by the last couple of episodes. They had a lot of potential, a great and fairly unique story and the characters were quite enjoyable, I felt as if the anime was cut short of a great story.
Story 6/10
The story also had the potential of a 9 or even a 10. The thought of an alternate dimension that was the demonic version of ourworld sounded like it was about survival mystery and could have been very complex. However, the story was not fleshed out enough and the development of the story went relatively slow. All except the end where there was suddenly some historical background information thrown at us at the last second. The plot was somewhat disappointing and predictable, as I was very disappointed in the story.


Art 8/10


There is not much to say about the artwork but the fact that you could tell the animators undoubtedly put work in it. The graphics were great and the effects were well done as well but nothing overly spectacular. The colors matched the mood of the anime well and art was definitely one of the highlights to 11eyes.


Sound 10/10


Nothing I say will do the music justice in this anime. Watch the openings and endings and the amazing soundtracks and see for yourself. 


Character 6/10


Similar to the plot, the characters had so much potential. However, their back-stories were simply thrown at it as we couldn't adjust to it long enough to understand these characters. Instead, at the end they unfortunately

became cliche and forgettable characters.


Enjoyment 8/10


Even to my disappointment at the end, the anime itself was good and was fun to watch. In the beginning and middle of the anime, the characters were fun and I nonetheless enjoyed it. The scenario they were in made the characters very interesting. However, of course, an ending could either make or break an anime, and this one not the worst but is very lacking.


Overall 7/10


This anime had great potential, but lacked a lot. My main problem was that it was too short and at least 24 episodes would be good. I hope for another season, but I really doubt it since it has been so long. Even through all my criticizing, this is in no way a terrible, let alone bad anime. It was enjoyable and the characters were fun. The soundtrack and graphics were unforgettable you'll definitely be humming it some time in the future. This is still an okay anime, and if you like supernatural anime, you may consider watching this. I make no promises though.

11eyes starts off as a stereotypical visual novel adaption. You have your male protagonist who has his own personal issues, the best friend who (not-so-secretly) loves him, and your secondary characters that introduce themselves several moments after the first climax. You also hear the “I will protect you” line played almost every episode in between the “make the useless male protagonist into a hero” training scenes. In a nutshell, aside from the unique set up of the story, everything else is simply predictable and average. All of the characters, save for one or two, could have been generated from a cookie-cutter, but even that isnot a huge issue. What turned this average series into a disappointing one was Satsuki Kakeru and Minase Yuka’s performance as the main leads. It made me cringe every time they stepped into the spotlight and it is difficult to enjoy a series when you despise the protagonists that much.


The story itself starts off with a fair number of questions. What is the Red Night? Who are the Dark Knights? What makes these kids so special? However, these questions are answered later rather than sooner. And when they are answered, you’re left with more questions than when you started because of the “unexpected” twist they throw at you near the end. The ending can come across as either unique and satisfying or random and unexpected depending on how well you can accept the facts at face value. Unfortunately, I could not appreciate the ending because I felt its plot was poorly executed. It had a lot of potential in the beginning and even in the middle, but I could not get past the plot holes they left unfilled along the way.


Although the series as a whole seemed like a let-down, there are a lot of promising areas that kept my attention. Aside from the main love triangle, which was super awkward, I found myself focusing my attention more towards the other characters’ relationships. The secondary characters all have interesting histories and stories that get revealed little by little each episode. The antagonists also have interesting backgrounds, though it is revealed way too late to mean much, but it does help show that their intentions are not just to be bad for the sake of being bad.


I feel like I am not giving 11eyes enough credit because in all honesty, it probably deserves more. However, I would not advise you to go watch it just to go looking for its good points since there is very little to find. As much as I tried to enjoy 11eyes, in the end I found myself watching the last few episodes for a sense of closure more than anything else. I watched it as a way to pass the time in between other shows… and trust me, it did not make time go by any faster.

character 7/10

Other charactes are pretty balance. Putting the yandere aside, there are also an energetic girl, a dandere, and a sempai. They have their own reason to fight, but at the end their paths lead to one conclusion.\n\n
